name: stibnite mine operation and beneficiation | stibnite concentrate | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/12096/documentation

The dataset exchanges are identical to the CN dataset. Created to enable linking to regional markets (e.g. electricity). Data quality indicators adjusted accordingly.;The original CN dataset represents mining and beneficiation of Stibnite and the production of stibnite concentrate from it in China. Stibnite is the main source for antimony production. 60% of globally mined antimony is mined in China and with their import surtplus, over 80% of the global Antimony is produced there.;Due to lack of information about the mining of stibnite, this dataset is mainly approximated with data from the mining and beneficiation of molybdenite from coupled production with copper (Classen et al., 2009). This dataset should not be used if its relative importance is high in the product system that is modelled. For more details about the origin of the data, refer to the Sampling Procedure and exchange comments.

This activity starts with the extraction of stibnite ore from the ground.

The activity includes the mining and the beneficiation step with the mining infrastructure and disposal of overburden and tailings.
category: B:Mining and quarrying/07:Mining of metal ores/072:Mining of non-ferrous metal ores/0729:Mining of other non-ferrous metal ores

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The dataset exchanges are identical to CN dataset. Created to enable linking to regional markets (e.g. for electricity). Data quality indicators adjusted accordingly
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: This dataset is approximated with values from molybdenum mining and beneficiation (coupled with copper mining). See Classen et al (2009) Part XVI.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Dataset created using identical exchanges to CN dataset. Created to enable linking to regional markets (e.g. electricity). Data quality indicators adjusted accordingly.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
Data retrieved from:
Classen M., Althaus H.-J., Blaser S., Doka G., Jungbluth N., Tuchschmid M. (2009) Life Cycle Inventories of Metals, Final report ecoinvent data v2.1, 10, Dübendorf, CH, Swiss Centre for LCI, Empa - TSL, 3 - SeparatePublication, CD-ROM

Jianwen Chu, Jiansu Mao, Mengchang He (2019). Anthropogenic antimony flow analysis and evaluation in China. Science of The Total Environment, Volume 683. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.scitotenv.2019.05.293

exchanges.description: The Antimony content is based on the values in "Anthropogenic antimony flow analysis and evaluation in China" J. Chu et al., 2019

exchanges.description:
The amount as well as the antimony content is based on the values in "Anthropogenic antimony flow analysis and evaluation in China" J. Chu et al., 2019 and certain assumptions. 
The recovery rate at milling is reported to be 84.76%, which, with a Sb content in the concentrate of 0.2683 results in ~0.3165 kg of Sb retrieved from the ground per kg of concentrate. Multiplying this with the milling losses of 0.1524 equals ~0.04824 kg of Sb landing in tailings per kg of concentrate. The reported tailings concentration of 1.4% then results in ~3.446 kg tailings per kg concentrate.

exchanges.description:
Amount calculated based on mass balance. Since Sulfur is not separately mentioned in the inputs, the sulfur contained in the stibnite is considered to be Gangue. 
Based on the mass balance per kg of concentrate 1 - 0.2683 = 0.7317 kg   ending up in the concentrate and 3.446 * ( 1 - 0.02 ) = 3.37708  kg ending up in tailings.
Subtracting the lime stone the following overall amount results: 0.7317 + 3.37708 - 0.19796 kg = 3.91082 kg
